subj-group.subject: Physics: Smart Photonic and Optoelectronic Materials

title-group.article-title: CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films with efficient interfacial charge transfer characteristics for optoelectronic applications

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films were synthesized through the oxidation of nanostructured Cu–Zn films deposited by vacuum deposition technique at a relatively high pressure of an inert gas. XRD patterns showed that the film samples were nanocomposites containing nanograins of CuO and ZnO and that the size of the CuO grains decreased with the increase in the Zn atom %. Optical absorption and Raman spectra confirmed the samples to be nanocomposites. The decrease in the activation energy for DC conduction and the enhancement in the photocurrent in the CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films with the increase in the atom % of Zn were attributed to an efficient interfacial charge transfer between the CuO and ZnO grains.

notes.title: Electronic supplementary material
notes.p: The online version of this article (https://doi.org/10.1007/s42452-019-1002-6) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nanocomposite materials are composed of multiple phases with at least one among these phases having a nanoscale structure [2, 6, 22, 30, 31, 33, 35, 40] for imparting its size-dependent attributes to the nanocomposite. Nanocomposites have the potential for combining the desirable properties of different nanoscale building blocks offering an opportunity to tailor the properties of materials for fabrication of devices for specific applications [5, 10, 20]. For optoelectronic and photocatalysis applications of nanocomposites of n- and p-type semiconductors, efficient inter-grain charge transfer between semiconductor phases is of crucial importance. The existence of multiple interface junctions between grains in multi-component semiconductor nanocomposites facilitates easy charge interaction enabling turning of optical and electrical properties of these systems. In the case of ZnO-CuO nanocomposite mesocrystals, Bian et al. [9] observed that ZnO and CuO are n-type and p-type semiconductors, respectively, and since the conduction and valence bands for CuO lie above those of ZnO, photogenerated electrons and holes in ZnO easily get transferred, respectively, to the conduction band and valance band of CuO.

Nanocomposites of different combinations of materials such as metal–metal [24], metal–polymer [28], metal–dielectric [39], dielectric–metal [26], semiconductor–polymer [15], semiconductor–dielectric [18] and semiconductor–semiconductor [27] have been synthesized and studied for specific applications. Nanocomposites have also been synthesized in different forms like powders [17], mesocrystals [23] and films [7, 9, 13, 29]. For technological applications of nanocomposites, it is desirable to be able to prepare these nanocomposites in the form of films, and more importantly, it would be advantageous if both or all the components of the nanocomposite are in the nanosize regime. These requirements necessitate that both the components of a two phase nanocomposite should be generated as nanoparticles which deposit simultaneously on substrates to form of nanostructured films with non-resistive interparticle contacts. [27] used atomic layer chemical vapor deposition to infiltrate CuInS2 inside the pores of nanostructured TiO2 to prepare nanocomposite of n-type TiO2 and p-type CuInS2. [7] employed radiofrequency sputtering to produce CdTe-ZnO nanocomposite thin films with varied semiconductor-phase extended structures and studied the optical absorption and the carrier transport behavior of these films. [29] used a dual-source, sequential radiofrequency sputter deposition technique to study the spatial distribution of CdTe nanoparticles within ZnO thin-film matrix. [37] demonstrated that the CuO–ZnO heterostructured device is an effective visible-light-driven photocatalyst for environmental remediation or solar energy conversion. [11] reported the synthesis and characterization of p-CuO/n-ZnO heterojunction nanocomposites and their application as a broad spectrum photocatalyst. An enhancement of power conversion efficiency (PCE) for ZnO/Cu2O solar cells with perfectly oriented and micrometer grain-sized Cu2O films was experimentally demonstrated [38]. Abraham et al. [1] reported band gap tuning of visible-light active heterojunction CuO/ZnO nanocomposites for dye-sensitized solar cell applications. In the present work, copper oxide–zinc oxide (CuO–ZnO) nanocomposite films were synthesized from p-type CuO and n-type ZnO semiconductors through the oxidation of Cu–Zn nanocomposite films deposited on glass substrates for four different atom % of Zn by vacuum deposition technique at a relatively high pressure of an inert gas [4, 21, 34]. The nanocomposite film samples were analyzed using X-ray diffraction, atomic force microscopy, UV–vis absorption spectroscopy and micro-Raman spectroscopy. DC conductivity, Hall measurements and photocurrent response of the film samples were studied, and the results confirmed the non-resistive interparticle contacts between the nanograins of the CuO and ZnO phases demonstrating the usefulness of the present deposition technique for fabrication of nanocomposite films of variable composition useful for optoelectronic applications.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p:
Copper oxide–zinc oxide (CuO–ZnO) nanocomposite films were prepared by oxidation of Cu–Zn nanocomposite films deposited on glass substrates by thermal co-evaporation of metallic Cu and Zn using a vacuum coating unit. Glass substrates were cleaned by a standard procedure [4, 21, 34]. Thermal co-evaporation of Cu and Zn was carried out at a pressure of 2 × 10−4 mbar of nitrogen in the vacuum chamber. Supersaturation of the inert gas in the deposition chamber with vapors of Cu and Zn resulted in the nucleation and growth of nanocrystals of Cu and Zn which deposited on the substrate as nanocomposite Cu–Zn films. Cu–Zn nanocomposite films were deposited for four different ratios of atom % (at%) of Cu and Zn, viz. 95:5, 90:10, 80:20 and 60:40. These films were oxidized at a temperature of 400 °C to obtain nanocomposite films of CuO–ZnO of different compositions. The atom % Cu and Zn in the film samples were determined by EDS analysis using JEOL Model JED—2300 energy-dispersive spectrometer, and the results are shown in Table 1 along with the sample codes. The crystallinity, crystal structure and grain size of the film samples were investigated using Bruker AXS D8 advance X-ray diffractometer with GIXRD attachment. The average thickness of the film samples was determined using a Veeco Dektak-6M stylus profiler (Table 1). AFM measurements on the film samples were taken using Digital Instruments Nanoscope E and with a Si3N4 100 µm cantilever having a force constant of 0.58 Nm−1 in contact mode. SAED pattern of the sample was obtained using JEOL JEM-2100 high-resolution transmission electron microscope. The optical transmission spectra of the film samples were recorded using a JASCO V-650 double-beam spectrophotometer. Photoluminescence of the samples was measured using Jobin–Yvon FLUOROLOG-FL3-11 spectrofluorometer. For DC electrical conductivity measurements, planar silver electrodes were deposited on the films at a distance of ~ 2 mm. Voltage–current (V–I) measurements were taken using a Keithley 2400 source meter, and linear V–I plots confirmed the Ohmic nature of the contacts of the electrodes with the film samples. Time-dependent photoresponse of the samples was measured using a 100-W halogen lamp as the light source with an applied voltage of 4 V between the electrodes. The geometry of the samples for photocurrent measurement was thin films with silver electrodes of length 1 cm painted on the surface of the films at a distance of 2 mm. The power density on the sample surface measured using Oriel Instruments USA 70260 power meter and Oriel Instruments USA 70424 detector was ~ 14.7 mW. Also, Hall measurements were taken on the samples using Ecopia HMS-5000 Hall effect measurement system.Table 1

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the GIXRD patterns of copper oxide–zinc oxide (CuO–ZnO) nanocomposite films CZ1, CZ2, CZ3 and CZ4 containing different atom % of Zn (Table 1). The GIXRD patterns of the film samples containing Zn concentration of ~ 3 atom % (CZ1) and ~ 8 atom % (CZ2) in Fig. 1a and b, respectively, show two prominent peaks at 2θ values of 35.6° and 38.8° corresponding to (-111) and (200) directions and a weak peak at 2θ = 48.9° corresponding to (− 202) direction of CuO (ICCD File No. 48-1548). In addition, (100) direction of ZnO appears as a very weak peak at 31.7° in Fig. 1a and b. The GIXRD pattern (Fig. 1c) of the sample CZ3 containing ~ 20 atom % of Zn shows, in addition to the CuO peaks seen in Fig. 1a and b, peaks at 2θ = 31.7°, 34.4° and 36.3° representing the (100), (002) and (101) directions of ZnO of hexagonal structure (ICDD file 36-1451). The GIXRD pattern of the sample CZ4 (Fig. 1d) containing ~ 40 atom % of Zn is similar to that of the sample CZ3 but with the intensity of (100), (002) and (101) peaks increased considerably and also shows other peaks of ZnO (Fig. 2). Fig. 1
GIXRD patterns of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different Zn at%: a ~ 3 at%, b ~ 8 at%, c ~ 20 at% and d ~ 40 at%Fig. 2
SAD pattern of nanocomposite CuO–ZnO film containing ~ 40 atom % of Zn

GIXRD patterns in Fig. 1 reveal that the CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different at% of Zn have crystalline structure and that the films have no preferential orientation. The XRD patterns of samples containing lower at% of Zn (Fig. 1a, b) show a weak peak of the ZnO corresponding to (100) direction indicating the existence of ZnO as a separate phase of along with the major phase (Zn-doped CuO). The substitutional incorporation of dopant atoms in a host material would affect the atomic scattering factor and the structure factor causing change in the relative intensities of the diffraction peaks [8, 25]. In the case of Co-doped ZnO nanocrystals, Bhattacharyya and Gedanken [8] observed that the relative intensity of XRD peaks varied with the increase in Co concentration and reported that the interplay of the XRD peak intensities with the Co concentrations was possible only if Co2+ substituted Zn2+ in the ZnO lattice to form Zn1-xCoxO. The atomic scattering factor is equal to the number of electrons in each atom and is 29 and 30 for Cu and Zn, respectively. Hence, the replacement of Cu2+ by Zn2+ may be expected to increase the intensity of a particular XRD peak depending on the structure factor. The variations in the intensities of the XRD peaks due to substitution of Cu2+ by Zn2+ should follow a certain trend with the increase in Zn concentration [8]. As per the ICDD pattern of CuO (ICDD File No. 48-1548), the relative intensities of the (− 111) and (200) peaks are in the ratio 5:1, while this ratio changed to 5:4 and 4:5 in the GIXRD patterns of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing Zn atom % of ~ 3 and ~ 8, respectively, indicating that Zn is substitutionally incorporated into the CuO nanograins in the films in addition to existing as a separate ZnO phase. The GIXRD patterns of CZ3 and CZ4 containing Zn atom % of ~ 20 and ~ 40 in Fig. 1c and d, respectively, show that the intensity of ZnO peaks increased with the increase in Zn at%. In these samples, ZnO exists as a separate phase and hence these samples are confirmed to be copper oxide–zinc oxide nanocomposite films. In Fig. 1c and d, the ratio of intensities of (− 111) to (200) peaks of CuO is 5:2 and 5:3, respectively, indicating phase separation in addition to substitutional incorporation of Zn into CuO lattice. The observation of variation of XRD peak intensities of the present samples is in agreement with the reported results [8].

SAD pattern of the sample CZ4 shows diffraction rings corresponding to both CuO and ZnO phases indicating the coexistence of the two phases in the film sample. The results from the XRD and SAD patterns provide the basis for the samples to be described as CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films. Although the ionic radii of Cu2+ (0.073 nm) and Zn2+ (0.074 nm) are almost equal, the formation of a solid solution of CuO and ZnO is not likely because of the difference in the preferred coordination environment of Cu2+ ions in CuO (Jahn–Teller distorted octahedral coordination) and Zn2+ ions in ZnO (tetrahedral coordination) [9]. Because of the difference in the coordination environment preferred by the two ions, CuO and ZnO are phase separated instead of formation of a solid solution, as observed in the present study.

The AFM images of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different Zn atom % of ~ 3, ~ 8, ~ 20 and ~ 40 are shown, respectively, in Fig. 3a–d. The AFM images of all the samples show particles of almost spherical shape with well-defined grain boundaries, but the size of the particles shows a drastic decrease with the increase in the atom % of Zn. The sizes of the particles obtained from AFM images are larger compared to those obtained from XRD analysis, this difference in the sizes being due to that the particles seen in the AFM images are actually aggregates of the primary particles. Fractal analysis can be used to understand the mechanism of aggregation of primary particles forming the larger aggregates which formed the nanocomposite films. The models generally used to explain atomic-scale aggregation are ballistic aggregation (BA), cluster–cluster aggregation (CCA) and diffusion limited aggregation (DLA). In the present study, the fractal dimensions of the films were determined by using SPIP post-image processing software. All the film samples exhibited fractal dimensions greater than 2 representing motion of particles along straight trajectories until they encounter the growing aggregates and stick to their surface which is termed ballistic aggregation mechanism [36] (Table 1). The formation of nanocrystals may be through CCA, while their deposition on the substrate may be through BA [4, 19, 36]. The increase in the fractal dimension of the films with the increase in the Zn concentration (Table I) may be interpreted as an indication of packing of the particles with stronger interparticle contacts aiding easy charge transfer between the particles.Fig. 3
AFM images of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different Zn concentrations a ~ 3 atom %, b ~ 8 atom %, c ~ 20 atom % and d ~ 40 atom %

The optical transmittance spectra of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films in Fig. S3 (Supplementary Information) show that the transmittance decreased with the increase in the atom % of Zn in the samples. The optical absorption coefficient (α) in the fundamental absorption region was calculated using the equation, α = (lnT−1)/t, where t is the film thickness and T the transmittance. For direct transition, the absorption coefficient is given by αhν = A (hν−Eg)1/2 where A is a constant, h is the Plank’s constant, ν is the frequency of the incident photon and Eg is the band gap energy. (αhν)2 was plotted against photon energy, hν (Tauc’s plot), and the value of Eg was determined from the intercept of the straight line fit to the linear portion of the plot with the abscissa.

The Tauc plots of all the four samples in Fig. 4 give two band gap energy values Eg1 and Eg2. With the increase in the atom % of Zn in the samples, Eg1 which is close to the band gap of CuO decreases, while the value of Eg2 increases toward the band gap of ZnO. The change in the optical absorption characteristics of the nanocomposite films compared to those of CuO and ZnO may be expected to arise from the interaction and phase connectivity between the CuO and ZnO nanoparticles constituting the films [7]. As reported by Potter et al. [29] in the case of CdTe-ZnO nanocomposite thin films, the increased concentration of ZnO in the present CuO–ZnO nanocomposites films provides increased physical and electronic isolation of adjacent CuO particles causing a reduction in the effective carrier confinement volume leading to a general increase in the lowest optical transition energy observed in the absorption spectrum of the samples.Fig. 4
Plot of (αhν)2 against hν for CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different Zn concentrations: a ~ 3 atom %, b ~ 8 atom %, c ~ 20 atom % and d ~ 40 atom %

Figure 5 shows the photoluminescence (PL) spectra of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films for different at% of Zn. All the samples show peaks around 361, 421, 440 and 529 nm. The peak around 361 nm is the band edge emission of ZnO [12]. The emission at 421 nm is attributed to the oxygen vacancy level in ZnO [3]. According to literature report, emission bands around 450–800 nm originate from defect-mediated charge recombination on the ZnO surface [16]. The peaks observed at 440 and 529 nm can be attributed to various defect-related emissions from ZnO. The intensity of all the peaks increased with the increase in the atom % of Zn, indicating that the observed emissions are from the ZnO phase.Fig. 5
Photoluminescence spectra of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different Zn at%: a ~ 3 at%, b ~ 8 at%, c ~ 20 at% and d ~ 40 at%

Figure 6 shows the micro-Raman spectra of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films recorded using an excitation wavelength of 488 nm. The spectra of all the four samples show distinct Raman lines at 297, 345 and 632 cm−1. The Raman line at 298 cm−1 corresponds to the Ag mode, while those at 348 and 631 cm−1 are the Bg modes of CuO. The Raman spectrum of CZ4 containing Zn concentration of ~ 40 atom % shows an additional peak at ~ 566 cm−1 due to the A1 (LO) mode of ZnO indicating the existence of ZnO phase in the nanocomposite films [32]. The peak around 593 cm−1 is reported as the E1 longitudinal mode of ZnO [14]. This peak is visible only in the sample CZ3. The presence of Raman peaks of both CuO and ZnO showed the samples to be CuO–ZnO nanocomposites.Fig. 6
Micro-Raman spectra of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different Zn concentrations a ~ 3 at%, b ~ 8 at%, c ~ 20 at% and d ~ 40 at%

The time response of photocurrent in the CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films in Fig. 9 shows that the photocurrent increased with the increase in the at% of Zn in the films. Theoretically, when light is switched on or off, there should be a sudden rise or fall of photocurrent followed by a slow rise or decay process, respectively. The sudden rise in the photocurrent is due to the rapid generation of electrons and holes upon illumination, while the sudden drop in the photocurrent is due to the cessation of electron–hole pair generation. In the present study, a sudden rise in the photocurrent followed by a slow decay process was observed.Fig. 9
Photoresponse of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different Zn at%: a ~ 3 at%, b ~ 8 at%, c ~ 20 at% and d ~ 40 at%

Figure 9 shows that the photocurrent increased rapidly with the increase in the at% of Zn in the samples. One of the important characteristics of photodetectors is their quick response to the incoming photosignal, i.e., the rise time of photocurrent after the incidence of light, and the fall time of photocurrent after the removal of light should be small, and should be tunable. From Fig. 9, it can be seen that both these parameters decrease with the increase in the Zn wt % in the samples. While the larger magnitude of photocurrent in CZ4 is attributable to the increased Zn at% dependent photogeneration of charge carriers, the lower rise time for sample for CZ4 compared to that for CZ1 can be attributed to the larger mobility of charge carriers in CZ4. In the present study, strong interparticle contacts between the CuO and ZnO grains could lead to efficient interfacial charge transfer resulting in the observed increased photocurrent in the films containing higher Zn at%. The enhancement in the photocurrent in the CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films with the increase in the at% of Zn can be attributed to an increased photogeneration of electron–hole pairs and to the increased mobility. Efficient photoinduced charge transfer between different semiconducting phases of nanocomposites is of crucial importance for photocatalysis and optoelectronic applications. The feasibility to tune the photoresponse by varying the Zn at % in CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films synthesized through the present technique would provide an opportunity for maximizing the performance of optoelectronic devices based on this and similar systems.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Vacuum deposition technique at a relatively high pressure of an inert gas was used for the synthesis of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films containing different atom % of Zn. The samples were characterized using different experimental techniques. DC conductivity and photocurrent measurements were carried out on the samples. The existence of multiple interface junctions between grains in multi-component semiconductor nanocomposites facilitates easy charge interaction enabling turning of optical and electrical properties of these systems. In the present case of CuO–ZnO nanocomposite samples, it was observed that CuO and ZnO are p-type and n-type semiconductors, respectively, and since the conduction and valence bands for CuO lie above those of ZnO, photogenerated electrons and holes in ZnO get easily transferred, respectively, to the conduction band and valance band of CuO. The decrease in the activation energy for DC conduction and the increase in the photocurrent in the CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films with the increase in the at% of Zn were attributed to an efficient interfacial charge transfer between the CuO and ZnO nanograins. The feasibility to tune the photoresponse by varying the Zn at % in CuO–ZnO nanocomposite films synthesized through the present technique would provide an opportunity for maximizing the performance of optoelectronic devices based on this and similar systems.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The author M. A. K expresses his gratitude to the University Grants Commission for sanctioning him a fellowship under its Emeritus Fellowship Scheme. The authors thank Dr. V. Ganesan, Centre Director, and Dr.V.G Sathe and Dr. V. R. Reddy, Scientists, IUC-DAE—CSR, Indore, for providing facilities for AFM, micro-Raman and GIXRD measurements and Dr. K. P. Vijayakumar, CUSAT, Kochi, for extending facilities for Hall measurements. We express our sincere thanks to Dr. Sabu Thomas, School of Chemical Sciences, Mahatma Gandhi University, Kottayam, for providing TEM facility.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
